articles.headline: Narges Mohammadi, Iranian Rights Activist, Receives Nobel Peace Prize
articles.snippet: Ms. Mohammadi, currently held in Tehran’s notorious Evin Prison, has pushed for peaceful change in Iran for 30 years, with a focus on women’s equality.
articles.abstract: Ms. Mohammadi, currently held in Tehran’s notorious Evin Prison, has pushed for peaceful change in Iran for 30 years, with a focus on women’s equality.
articles.lead_paragraph: Narges Mohammadi, Iran’s most prominent human rights activist and an inmate in the country’s notorious Evin Prison, was awarded the 2023 Nobel Peace Prize on Friday, in an effort by the Norwegian Nobel Committee to support women’s rights in Iran.
articles.byline: By Farnaz Fassihi

articles.headline: Gary Wang, an FTX Founder, Says Sam Bankman-Fried Steered Misuse of Funds
articles.snippet: Mr. Wang is one of three key witnesses who pleaded guilty and agreed to cooperate against Mr. Bankman-Fried, the onetime crypto mogul on trial for fraud.
articles.abstract: Mr. Wang is one of three key witnesses who pleaded guilty and agreed to cooperate against Mr. Bankman-Fried, the onetime crypto mogul on trial for fraud.
articles.lead_paragraph: Gary Wang, a former top executive of the failed FTX cryptocurrency exchange, testified that Sam Bankman-Fried, the company’s founder, was the final decision maker at the firm and directed a closely related hedge fund to misuse as it pleased billions of dollars in money from FTX customers.
articles.byline: By David Yaffe-Bellany, J. Edward Moreno and Matthew Goldstein

articles.headline: How Do Americans Feel About Politics? ‘Disgust Isn’t a Strong Enough Word’
articles.snippet: Voters’ broad discontent with disarray in Washington transcends political parties, race, age and geography.
articles.abstract: Voters’ broad discontent with disarray in Washington transcends political parties, race, age and geography.
articles.lead_paragraph: Whitney Smith’s phone buzzed with a text from her mother, alerting her to the latest can-you-believe-it mess in Washington: “Far right ousted the House speaker. Total chaos now.”
articles.byline: By Jack Healy, J. David Goodman, Jenna Russell and Alan Blinder

articles.headline: How Biden’s Promises to Reverse Trump’s Immigration Policies Crumbled
articles.snippet: President Biden has tried to contain a surge of migration by embracing, or at least tolerating, some of his predecessor’s approaches.
articles.abstract: President Biden has tried to contain a surge of migration by embracing, or at least tolerating, some of his predecessor’s approaches.
articles.lead_paragraph: Immigration was dead simple when Joseph R. Biden Jr. was campaigning for president: It was an easy way to attack Donald J. Trump as a racist, and it helped to rally Democrats with the promise of a more humane border policy.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear

articles.headline: Interested in an Electric Vehicle? Consider Buying Used.
articles.snippet: The prices of used battery-powered models have fallen sharply, as the supply of cars and trucks has improved.
articles.abstract: The prices of used battery-powered models have fallen sharply, as the supply of cars and trucks has improved.
articles.lead_paragraph: If you’re in the market for an electric vehicle, the time might be right to consider a used one.
articles.byline: By Santul Nerkar

articles.headline: In Provence, Winemakers Confront Climate Change
articles.snippet: Centuries-old varieties are being altered by weather patterns, threatening the economics of businesses in one of the world’s most important regions.
articles.abstract: Centuries-old varieties are being altered by weather patterns, threatening the economics of businesses in one of the world’s most important regions.
articles.lead_paragraph: “You can taste the climate change.”
articles.byline: By Patricia Cohen and Violette Franchi

articles.headline: Two Families Got Fed Up With Their States’ Politics. So They Moved Out.
articles.snippet: The Nobles of Iowa moved to blue Minnesota. The Huckinses of Oregon moved to red Missouri. Their separate journeys, five weeks apart, illustrate the fracturing of America.
articles.abstract: The Nobles of Iowa moved to blue Minnesota. The Huckinses of Oregon moved to red Missouri. Their separate journeys, five weeks apart, illustrate the fracturing of America.
articles.lead_paragraph: Steve Huckins, a native of Oregon, was preparing to move across the country when he went on Facebook to post a goodbye letter of sorts to his home state.
articles.byline: By Trip Gabriel and Hilary Swift

articles.headline: An Attack From Gaza and an Israeli Declaration of War. Now What?
articles.snippet: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is being pressured to launch a full-scale invasion that Israeli leaders have been scrupulously avoiding since 2005.
articles.abstract: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is being pressured to launch a full-scale invasion that Israeli leaders have been scrupulously avoiding since 2005.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nearly 50 years to the day after the Yom Kippur war of 1973, Israel has again been taken by surprise by a sudden attack, a startling reminder that stability in the Middle East remains a bloody mirage.
articles.byline: By Steven Erlanger

articles.headline: ‘The Children Were Terrified.’ Fear Grips Israel and Gaza
articles.snippet: As Hamas launched a surprise attack on southern Israel, Israelis huddled in shelters and Gazans flocked to supermarkets, fearing the Israeli military response.
articles.abstract: As Hamas launched a surprise attack on southern Israel, Israelis huddled in shelters and Gazans flocked to supermarkets, fearing the Israeli military response.
articles.lead_paragraph: Israeli citizens, barricaded in their homes in towns near the Gaza Strip, called into television stations as Palestinian gunmen crossed the border into Israel and invaded their communities on Saturday morning. The Israelis spoke in whispers as they pleaded desperately for help.
articles.byline: By Isabel Kershner and Raja Abdulrahim

articles.headline: ‘We Are at War,’ Netanyahu Says After Hamas Attacks Israel
articles.snippet: Palestinian militants from Gaza launched an early-morning assault on southern Israel, invading towns and firing thousands of rockets. Israel retaliated with huge strikes on Gazan cities.
articles.abstract: Palestinian militants from Gaza launched an early-morning assault on southern Israel, invading towns and firing thousands of rockets. Israel retaliated with huge strikes on Gazan cities.
articles.lead_paragraph: Israel battled on Saturday to repel one of the broadest invasions of its territory in 50 years after Palestinian militants from Gaza launched an early-morning assault on southern Israel, infiltrating 22 Israeli towns and army bases, kidnapping Israeli civilians and soldiers and firing thousands of rockets toward cities as far away as Jerusalem.
articles.byline: By Patrick Kingsley and Isabel Kershner

articles.headline: Rape, Race and a Decades-Old Lie That Still Wounds
articles.snippet: Farid El Haïry spent most of his adult life as a convicted rapist. Then his accuser changed her story.
articles.abstract: Farid El Haïry spent most of his adult life as a convicted rapist. Then his accuser changed her story.
articles.lead_paragraph: The phone echoed in Farid El Haïry’s home in northern France. It was February 1999.
articles.byline: By Catherine Porter and Aurelien Breeden

articles.headline: The Wager That Betting Can Change the World
articles.snippet: A coterie of tech insiders believe that “prediction markets” can fix social ills. Are they right?
articles.abstract: A coterie of tech insiders believe that “prediction markets” can fix social ills. Are they right?
articles.lead_paragraph: I had never before attended a business conference with a 28 percent chance of an orgy.
articles.byline: By Kevin Roose

articles.headline: Amid Strikes, One Question: Are Employers Miscalculating?
articles.snippet: UPS, the Hollywood studios and the Detroit automakers appear to have been taken aback by the tactics and tougher style adopted by new union leaders.
articles.abstract: UPS, the Hollywood studios and the Detroit automakers appear to have been taken aback by the tactics and tougher style adopted by new union leaders.
articles.lead_paragraph: The list of gains that the Hollywood writers secured to end a nearly five-month strike with studios once seemed ludicrously ambitious: not just wage increases, but also minimum staffing levels for shows, new royalties on successful series and restrictions on outsourcing writing duties to artificial intelligence.
articles.byline: By Noam Scheiber

articles.headline: A Texas Community Attracts Migrant Home Buyers, and Republican Ire
articles.snippet: The development near Houston offers cheap land and unconventional financing to buyers, many of them undocumented immigrants. Gov. Greg Abbott has called for hearings.
articles.abstract: The development near Houston offers cheap land and unconventional financing to buyers, many of them undocumented immigrants. Gov. Greg Abbott has called for hearings.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the dense, damp forests northeast of Houston, a pair of brothers hit on a viable real estate business model: Offer plots of cheap land and unconventional loans for people who wanted to build their own houses, with few restrictions.
articles.byline: By J. David Goodman and Danielle Villasana

articles.headline: Fearing Third-Party Spoilers vs. Trump, Biden Allies Try to Squash Them
articles.snippet: With Democrats worried that a third-party bid could throw a tight race to Donald Trump, President Biden’s top aides have blessed a broad offensive to starve such efforts of cash and ballot access.
articles.abstract: With Democrats worried that a third-party bid could throw a tight race to Donald Trump, President Biden’s top aides have blessed a broad offensive to starve such efforts of cash and ballot access.
articles.lead_paragraph: Powerful allies of President Biden are aggressively working to stop third-party and independent presidential candidacies, fearing that an outside bid could cost Democrats an election that many believe will again come down to a few percentage points in key battleground states.
articles.byline: By Reid J. Epstein and Lisa Lerer

articles.headline: A Shaken Israel Is Forced Back to Its Eternal Dilemma
articles.snippet: The attack by Hamas forces Israel once again to confront the conflict that has haunted it since the creation of the modern state.
articles.abstract: The attack by Hamas forces Israel once again to confront the conflict that has haunted it since the creation of the modern state.
articles.lead_paragraph: The most sweeping invasion of Israeli territory in decades, conducted by a Hamas force that had been widely seen as a ragtag collection of militants, has delivered a psychological shock to Israel so great that its very foundations are being questioned: its army, its intelligence services, its government and its capacity to control the millions of Palestinians in its midst.
articles.byline: By Roger Cohen

articles.headline: ‘There Were Terrorists Inside’: How Hamas’s Attack on Israel Unfolded
articles.snippet: Palestinian militants from Gaza raided Israel on Saturday, killing and abducting hundreds. Survivors have begun to recount the most complex attack on their territory in half a century.
articles.abstract: Palestinian militants from Gaza raided Israel on Saturday, killing and abducting hundreds. Survivors have begun to recount the most complex attack on their territory in half a century.
articles.lead_paragraph: The thousands of young Israelis had spent the night dancing at an outdoor rave, many clad in tie-dye T-shirts and crop tops.
articles.byline: By Patrick Kingsley, Aaron Boxerman and Gabby Sobelman

articles.headline: Israel and Hamas Battle Around Gaza as Netanyahu Warns of ‘Long and Difficult War’
articles.snippet: A senior Israeli defense official said that an early estimate showed about 700 Israelis were believed to be dead, and Gaza officials said more than 400 Palestinians have been killed.
articles.abstract: A senior Israeli defense official said that an early estimate showed about 700 Israelis were believed to be dead, and Gaza officials said more than 400 Palestinians have been killed.
articles.lead_paragraph: Israeli troops fought to expel Palestinian militants from Israeli territory for a second day on Sunday, battling in firefights between homes, ducking under rocket fire and striking Gazan cities from the sky in retaliation for the militants’ assault, which officials described as the worst attack on Israel in decades.
articles.byline: By Isabel Kershner and Patrick Kingsley

articles.headline: Hamas Attack Raises Questions Over an Israeli Intelligence Failure
articles.snippet: American and Israeli officials said none of Israel’s intelligence services had specific warning that Hamas was preparing a sophisticated assault.
articles.abstract: American and Israeli officials said none of Israel’s intelligence services had specific warning that Hamas was preparing a sophisticated assault.
articles.lead_paragraph: The devastating surprise attack by Hamas on Saturday represented an equally stunning intelligence failure by Israel that involved undetected warnings, overwhelmed missile defenses and a slow response by apparently unprepared military forces, former and current U.S. officials said.
articles.byline: By Julian E. Barnes, David E. Sanger and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Green Energy Casts a Shadow Over a Cherished English Landscape
articles.snippet: Residents of East Anglia fear that planned power lines for offshore wind projects will blight their rural idyll.
articles.abstract: Residents of East Anglia fear that planned power lines for offshore wind projects will blight their rural idyll.
articles.lead_paragraph: Charlotte Banks lives in a house that just about anyone would envy. Hempnalls Hall, a pink structure dating to the 16th century, rises above an even older moat, dug to keep marauders away in ancient times.
articles.byline: By Stanley Reed

articles.headline: Vaults, Ducts, Kitchens: Everything Must Go When a Company Moves Out
articles.snippet: As companies reduce their office footprint to accommodate remote work, they are turning to decommissioning teams to clear out furniture, fixtures and equipment.
articles.abstract: As companies reduce their office footprint to accommodate remote work, they are turning to decommissioning teams to clear out furniture, fixtures and equipment.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wayne Horne’s job comes with many challenges. This time, the problem was a generator that was too large to fit through its existing vent.
articles.byline: By Ellen Rosen

articles.headline: Russia’s Economy Is Increasingly Structured Around Its War in Ukraine
articles.snippet: The nation’s finances have proven resilient, despite punishing sanctions, giving it leeway to pump money into its military machine.
articles.abstract: The nation’s finances have proven resilient, despite punishing sanctions, giving it leeway to pump money into its military machine.
articles.lead_paragraph: “Everything needed for the front,” Russia’s finance minister declared, echoing a Soviet slogan from World War II as he talked about the government’s latest spending plans.
articles.byline: By Patricia Cohen

articles.headline: Scalise, a McCarthy Rival, Seeks to Unite Republicans in Taking His Place
articles.snippet: The second-ranking Republican, who was cut out of major decisions by the previous speaker, is pitching himself as uniquely positioned to unify the deeply divided House G.O.P.
articles.abstract: The second-ranking Republican, who was cut out of major decisions by the previous speaker, is pitching himself as uniquely positioned to unify the deeply divided House G.O.P.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Harriet M. Hageman announced her 2022 primary challenge against Representative Liz Cheney of Wyoming, House Republican leaders quickly endorsed her bid to oust a colleague whose condemnations of former President Donald J. Trump had made her a pariah in her own party.
articles.byline: By Annie Karni

articles.headline: Claudia Goldin Wins Nobel in Economics for Studying Women in the Work Force
articles.snippet: Her research uncovered the reasons for gender gaps in labor force participation and earnings. She is the third woman to win the prize.
articles.abstract: Her research uncovered the reasons for gender gaps in labor force participation and earnings. She is the third woman to win the prize.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences was awarded on Monday to Claudia Goldin, a Harvard professor, for advancing the world’s understanding of women’s progress in the work force.
articles.byline: By Jeanna Smialek
